body_html:
Personally, I'm often confused by what the gradient/derivative of x with respect t y means. But looking at the terminology used by the Wikipedia page for derivative (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derivative), I think ... x with respect to y tends to mean dx is the numerator and dy is the denominator, i.e. y is the function and x is the independent variable. So I think @ruimashita 's change is correct.

I'll defer to @alextp, who has done a lot of work on gradients in TF, for final approval.

body:
Personally, I'm often confused by what `the gradient/derivative of x with respect t y` means. But looking at the terminology used by the Wikipedia page for *derivative* (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derivative), I think `... x with respect to y` tends to mean `dx` is the numerator and `dy` is the denominator, i.e. `y` is the function and `x` is the independent variable. So I think @ruimashita 's change is correct.

I'll defer to @alextp, who has done a lot of work on gradients in TF, for final approval.
